Notes: HCM 2011 a resolution asking Congress to reduce administrative burden and allow states further flexibility in setting policies to address homelessness. Allowing states this flexibility will allow Arizona to develop an approach best suited to conditions on the ground instead of forcing them to follow a one-size-fits-all approach from Washington.

2025 HB 1512 is an education omnibus bill, which includes: broadening accelerated learning programs to include IB and dual enrollment in addition to AP; end DEI and loyalty oaths; bans excused absences for protesting, and requires parental permission for excused absences to participate in lobbying; increase accountability for tenured faculty; institute performance-based funding; streamline the admissions process and accept the Classical Learning Test; and increase access to scholarships. These reforms will make higher education in Arkansas more cost-effective and better at preparing Arkansas students for future success.

2025 SB 246 is an education omnibus bill, which includes: broadening accelerated learning programs to include IB and dual enrollment in addition to AP; end DEI and loyalty oaths; bans excused absences for protesting, and requires parental permission for excused absences to participate in lobbying; increase accountability for tenured faculty; institute performance-based funding; streamline the admissions process and accept the Classical Learning Test; and increase access to scholarships. These reforms will make higher education in Arkansas more cost-effective and better at preparing Arkansas students for future success.

2025 SB 537 allows a supervised offender in Arkansas to accrue work-for-time credits for every 30-day period in which they maintain eligible employment, which will benefit Arkansans by reducing recidivism.

2025 SB 602 allows international physicians to practice medicine in Arkansas without redoing residency, as long as they have a job offer from a healthcare provider in a medically underserved area of the state. This will both free up residency slots for US medical students and increase the pool of available doctors to serve Arkansans in underserved, particularly rural, areas.

2025 SR 64 is a resolution asking Congress to reduce administrative burden and allow states further flexibility in setting policies to address homelessness. Allowing states this flexibility will allow Arkansas to develop an approach best suited to conditions on the ground instead of forcing them to follow a one-size-fits-all approach from Washington.
2025 H 107 prevents government boards from imposing occupational licensing requirements or fees without legislative approval, removing a barrier to innovation and growth in Idaho.

2025 S.1141 bans public camping in Idaho cities larger than 100,000, which encompasses the state's 3 largest cities - Boise, Meridian, and Nampa. This will ensure that homeless people are off the streets and connected with the resources they need, which will help make Idaho's communities cleaner and safer.

2025 HB 1003 strengthens Indiana's Medicaid fraud control unit and requires clinical laboratories and diagnostic imaging facilities to post their prices online in order to increase transparency and lower the cost of healthcare through competition to keep prices low.

2025 HB 1006 creates a prosecutor review board, which will investigate any prosecutors who refuse to prosecute certain crimes or categories of crimes. Ensuring all crimes are prosecuted properly will improve the safety of the citizens of Indiana.

2025 HB 1555 allows the Medical Licensing Board of Indiana to issue limited licenses to international medical graduates to practice in underserved areas if they possess a written employment offer from a healthcare facility in an underserved area, in order to increase access to medical care in underserved - particularly rural - areas.

2025 HB 1604 requires that Indiana health plans credit out-of-pocket expenses toward deductibles if the amount paid is less than the plan's normal rate, which will incentivize patients to shop around for the lowest prices and incentivize providers to offer the lowest prices they can.

2025 SB 475 prohibits physicians from entering into noncompete agreements with hospitals or hospital systems in Indiana, in order to allow for greater competition and professional mobility and increase availability of health care for Indianans.

2025 HF 295 allows Iowa colleges and universities to choose any federally recognized accreditor, which will allow for more competition among accreditors and increase academic freedom for Iowa higher education.

2025 HF 437 establishes a Center for Intellectual Freedom at the University of Iowa, aimed at promoting teaching and research on historical ideas, traditions, and texts that have shaped American constitutional order and society, which will expand the availability of high-quality scholarship, expand intellectual diversity, and foster civic engagement.

2025 HF 440 requires advance notice for any proposed increase in tuition, fees, or charges at Iowa public universities, requires universities to have at least one degree program that can be completed in three years, and to implement a work-study program, all with the goal of making higher education more affordable and accessible for Iowans.
2025 HF 856 bans all public entities in Iowa from engaging in any DEI activities, in order to ensure Iowa governments do not engage in discriminatory DEI practices.
2025 HF 887 removes birth centers from the definition of institutional health facilities and Certificate of Need requirements, in order to make birth care in Iowa more accessible and affordable.

2025 SF 369 requires Iowa students to pass the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services Naturalization Civics Test to graduate from high school or receive a high school equivalency diploma, in order to ensure Iowa students have sufficient knowledge of American government as they become voting-age citizens.

2025 SB 166 removes unnecessary degree requirements from state jobs in Kansas, with exceptions. It expands employment opportunities for Kansans with relevant experience but without college degrees, and allows open positions to be filled more efficiently.

2025 SB 78 allows colleges to choose between recognized accreditors and prohibits accreditors from forcing violations of state law, which will allow for greater academic freedom and greater accountability for Kansas colleges and universities.

2025 HB 4 is a ban on discriminatory DEI offices, officers, and training in Kentucky public institutions of higher education, which will ensure freedom of thought and freedom from institutional discrimination for students, faculty, and staff.

2025 HB 6 implements cost-benefit analysis into the Kentucky administrative rulemaking process, and requires future regulations to be justified by having minimal economic impact or being required to comply with federal law or court orders, in order to reduce the regulatory burden on Kentucky citizens.

2025 HB 1203 bans public camping in Mississippi. This will ensure that homeless people are off the streets and connected with the resources they need, which will help make Mississippi's communities cleaner and safer.
2025 HB 590 expands access to electronic health records in Montana, in order to make it easier for patients to transfer their data to the doctor, hospital, or other provider they choose.

2025 SB 212 ensures that computational resources and AI will be covered by property rights, restricts ability of government to regulate AI, requires AI-managed critical infrastructure to develop risk management policies. This will ensure Montana strikes a balance of allowing innovation in the AI space while preserving the safety of Montana citizens.

2025 SB 217 establishes a system of work time credit for probationers and parolees, letting them reduce their sentences through employment assuming good behavior, in order to ease rehabilitation and reduce recidivism.
2025 LB 660 regulates the purchase of drones and includes regulatory venue freedom, a five-year review of all regulations, and a mandatory cost-benefit analysis of regulations in Nebraska.
2025 SB 1 creates two dedicated funds to support behavioral health issues, including mental health and substance abuse treatment, in order to better support New Mexicans struggling with those issues.

2025 SB 3 breaks down behavioral health services into regions in order to better address the needs of varying communities in New Mexico, and streamlines administrative procedures to increase efficiency.

2025 SB 375 allows minimum-risk defendants in New Mexico to be automatically released from probation after half their probation term if they meet all their obligations, removes the requirement for inmates to pay back the cost of parole, and includes reductions in sentence for completing education, in order to reduce recidivism and increase public safety in New Mexico.

2025 HB 1329 mandates a government efficiency study during the 2025-26 interim to assess the feasibility of creating a government spending database to assess spending efficiency and regulatory compliance in North Dakota state government.
2025 HB 1442 establishes a legislative task force on government efficiency to identify areas for increased efficiency and cost-saving measures for North Dakota.

2025 SB 1 makes several reforms to the Ohio higher education system, including requiring course syllabi to be publicly available, prohibits DEI practices, and prohibits state institutions of higher education from accepting gifts from China, in order to make the higher education system more transparent and to eliminate discriminatory DEI practices.

2025 HB 1595 increases penalties for assault and battery and adds specific penalties for domestic abuse in Oklahoma, in order to better protect law-abiding Oklahomans in general and victims of domestic violence in particular.

2025 HB 2050 allows Oklahoma to issue licenses to internationally trained physicians, including provisions for a probationary period, requirements for English proficiency, and a degree from a foreign medical school recognized by ECFMG, in order to increase the availability of healthcare practitioners in the state.

2025 SB 796 prohibits Oklahoma public institutions of higher education from using any state resources to support DEI programs, positions, or activities, in order to in order to foster intellectual diversity on Oklahoma campuses and protect the free speech rights of Oklahoma students.
2025 SB 164 requires regulations with a substantial economic impact to be given an assessment report before approval, in order to ensure additional oversight of regulations that carry sizable costs.
2025 HB 106 exempts drop-in centers and church and gym childcare rooms from needing to be licensed, which will increase the availability and affordability of childcare options in Tennessee.

2025 SB 871 requires the Tennessee government to study the current state of continuum of care in Tennessee in order to identify areas where the program can be made more efficient and effective in order to benefit both taxpayers and the homeless.

2025 SB 890 in Tennessee shortens the timeframe in which health records must be provided upon request, from 10 working days to 10 calendar days, in order to expedite patients' ability to access their health records.

2025 SB 1038 provides for rewards to individuals who report fraud and abuse in Medicaid if the report leads to a remedy, in order to provide a further source of oversight on the Medicaid system and increase accountability.

2025 SB 14 creates a regulatory efficiency office within Governor's office and an advisory panel of outside experts. These bodies will be required to publish an economic analysis and regulation reduction guide in order to increase efficiency and cost savings in Texas.

2025 SB 1080 allows Texas inmates to apply for occupational licenses while imprisoned, to be issued upon release, and allows the revocation of licenses for felony offenses, in order to provide Texas inmates with greater options for gainful employment upon release and to reduce recidivism.

2025 SB 617 requires hearings and public notice for Texas municipalities that convert properties into housing for homeless individuals, in order to allow Texas residents to be informed and have the opportunity to push back against decisions that could increase crime and other forms of disorder in their neighborhoods.

2025 SB 855 allows certain medical consenters to assume financial responsibility for out-of-network medical care provided to children in foster care, in order to allow more opportunities for children in foster care.

2025 SB 922 requires physicians to promptly provide patients with their medical information electronically, in order to allow Texas patients to more freely transfer their data between providers of their choosing.

2025 HB 163 creates a Division of Adult Probation and Parole within the Utah Department of Corrections and restructures requirements for compliance, in order to ensure special care is paid to probation and parole policies with the goal of reducing recidivism.

2025 HB 167 mandates local mental health authorities to coordinate with the Utah Department of Corrections to ensure a smooth transition in mental health services for individuals going onto probation or parole in order to reduce recidivisim and ensure proper continuity of care.

2025 HB 199 creates mobile opioid treatment units, bans supervised drug sites, bans syringe exchanges at drug-free zones in order to more effectively reduce the prevalence of drugs in Utah and ensure drug addicts receive proper treatment.
2025 HB 329 implements planning, data collection, and safety requirements for homeless services in Utah in order to increase effectiveness and decrease costs of these programs.

2025 HB 505 makes unsanctioned camping on state property a misdemeanor and requires municipalities comply with camping bans to be eligible for funding, in order to increase public safety for Utahns and ensure homeless individuals receive the care they need.

2025 HB 56 makes changes to Utah's involuntary commitment regulations - requiring a discharge plan, and laying out the procedure for involuntary civil commitment - in order to increase the health and safety of those who need urgent mental health care and the people around them.

HCR 6 is a resolution asking Congress to reduce administrative burden and allow states further flexibility in setting policies to address homelessness. Allowing states this flexibility will allow Utah to develop an approach best suited to conditions on the ground instead of forcing them to follow a one-size-fits-all approach from Washington.

2025 SB 121 creates a compensation fund for those who lose property value due to being close to homeless service facilities in Utah, in order to ensure that those who live near homeless services are compensated for the inconveniences it causes.
2025 SB 78 creates an ombudsman in the Utah Office of Homeless Services in order to make it easier for those in need of treatment to know what options are available.

2025 HB 1611 removes unnecessary degree requirements from state jobs in Virginia, with exceptions. It expands employment opportunities for Virginians with relevant experience but without college degrees, and allows open positions to be filled more efficiently.

2025 HB 1936 reduces required teacher training to once every 5 years, freeing up Virginia teachers to spend less time on compliance with government mandates and more time focusing on Virginia students.

2025 HB 2018 requires the Virginia Board of Education to create new pathways to renewable teacher licensure in career and technical education, including substituting work experience for education and reciprocity with out-of-state licenses, to make career and technical education more available and affordable for Virginians.

2025 HB 2053 requires the Virginia Department of Education to audit all education programs at public and private universities to check for compliance with laws relating to coursework, student mastery, and field experience in literacy instruction. This will increase accountability within teacher training programs and ensure that future generations of Virginia schoolchildren are receiving the highest possible quality of instruction.

2025 SB 1014 removes unnecessary degree requirements from state jobs in Virginia, with exceptions. It expands employment opportunities for Virginians with relevant experience but without college degrees, and allows open positions to be filled more efficiently.

2025 SB 1218 prohibits employers from enforcing a covenant not to compete against any low-wage employee in Virginia, which will increase opportunities for low-wage employees to find employment within their chosen field.

2025 SB 745 creates a stakeholder work group at the Virginia Board of Pharmacy to review the authority of pharmacists and potentially expand their scope of practice, which would expand healthcare access and options for Virginians.

2025 HB 147 is a ban on discriminatory DEI practices and loyalty oaths in any Wyoming government entities, which will ensure freedom of thought and freedom from institutional discrimination for those working for or interacting with the Wyoming government, including the education system.

2025 HB 289 repeals the final piece of Certificate of Need laws in Wyoming, which covers bed limitations on nursing homes. This policy change will allow for new healthcare options to open without being stifled by current healthcare interests seeking to limit competition.

2025 SF 79 provides for venue change for incorrect court venues in Wyoming, which can be done either by the court or by motion of either party. This ensures greater ease of access to petitioners not in a state capital's jurisdiction and potentially allows for fairer trials with more representative jury pools.
2025 SF 86 allows alternative certification methods for teachers, enabling alternative pathways to addressing teacher shortages and increasing access to and quality of education for Wyoming students.

2025 SF 107 is a full ban on noncompete agreements, with exceptions for senior leadership and trade secrets. It bans future and voids current noncompete clauses, which will benefit physicians currently covered by noncompete agreements and increase access to quality health care for the people of Wyoming.

2025 SF 127 is a major regulatory reform package, which includes provisions for cost-benefit analysis and 5-year sunsets of regulations, and the REINS act. Its passage, over the governor's veto, will significantly increase efficiency and legislative accountability in the Wyoming regulatory process.

2025 HB 24 revises the procedures for Texas local governments to change their zoning codes, making the notification requirements less burdensome. It also introduces a presumption of validity for zoning changes, enabling municipalities to automatically be able to enact zoning changes if not legally challenged, in order to allow Texas to address its housing shortages more efficiently and effectively.

2025 AB 547 limits the requirements of postsecondary degrees for state jobs in Nevada unless absolutely necessary and allows applicants to show alternative qualifications such as relevant work experience or non-degree credentials, in order to broaden the pool of qualified candidates and allow open positions to be filled more quickly and efficiently.

2025 HB 2540 requires health insurers to credit any amount an enrollee pays directly to a provider toward out-of-pocket costs and deductibles in Oregon. This incentivizes patients and providers alike to find ways to lower healthcare costs.

2024 HB 2490 allows a party appealing a final administrative decision in Arizona to choose any proper venue, rather than being limited to a court in the state capital, in order to reduce the institutional advantages bureaucracies can have when defending their decisions on their home turf and give more decisionmaking power to people in outer areas of the state who may be more adversely affected by agency policies.

2024 SB 1402 allows health insurers to create savings incentive programs for patients in Arizona who find prices for their treatment that is below the insurer's usual rates, granting them reimbursement for a portion of the difference. This incentivizes patients and providers alike to find ways to lower healthcare costs.
2024 SB24-141 allows out-of-state healthcare providers to offer telehealth services to Colorado patients, in order to increase availability and reduce costs of healthcare in Colorado.

Issues: Hospital Price Transparency; Patient's Right to Save
Notes: 2024 HB 7089 introduces requirements for medical facilities to post their prices in order to enable patients to shop around for the lowest prices, and adds a statute of limitations for collecting medical debt.

2024 CS/SB 7016 is a major healthcare reform in Florida, with many components; items of interest include expanding loan reimbursement to a wider range of healthcare practitioners such as dental hygienists; providing for telehealth for maternity care statewide; and increasing recognition of licenses from other states, in order to increase availability of medical providers in Florida.
2024 SB 7018 creates a Health Care Innovation Council in the Florida Department of Health to explore new ideas for improving access and affordability of health care in the state.

Issues: Camping Bans; Homelessness; Local Accountability; Mental Health Treatment; Sanctioned Camping Sites
Notes: 2024 CS/CS/HB 1365 prohibits Florida counties and municipalities from allowing unauthorized camping except in designated areas and allows residents, business owners, or the Attorney General to sue local governments that do not comply, in order to ensure that homeless people are off the streets and connected with the resources they need, which will help make Florida's communities cleaner and safer.

Issues: Drug-free Homeless Service Zones; Homelessness; Mental Health Treatment
Notes: 2024 HB 1410 establishes a state housing accountability program in Georgia, with an application process and requirements for job training and substance abuse treatment, and also includes oversight for how funds are being spent, in order to both provide needed services for homeless Georgians and also ensure public funds are being spent effectively.

2024 H 626 instructs Idaho courts not to defer to agencies' interpretations of administrative rules, which will increase the ability of the legislature and courts to set regulatory policy in the face of potential opposition from the bureaucracy.
2024 H 542 allows internationally licensed physicians to practice in Idaho, with a special focus on rural and primary care settings, in order to increase accessibility of care in underserved regions.

2024 H 563 requires a periodic review of Idaho administrative rules every eight years, with agencies reporting on the necessity of their rules to the legislature and considering whether the rules' content should be moved into statute, in order to better ensure Idaho administrative rules are necessary and beneficial for the citizens.

2024 H 433 limits the requirements of postsecondary degrees for state jobs in Idaho unless absolutely necessary and allows applicants to show alternative qualifications such as relevant work experience or non-degree credentials, in order to broaden the pool of qualified candidates and allow open positions to be filled more quickly and efficiently.

2024 H 436 creates the Idaho Allied Health Advisory Board, which will give guidance to the Idaho Board of Medicine on licensing of various types of health professionals, including dietitians, athletic trainers, and naturopathic practitioners, consolidating several previously existing boards into one. This will reduce administrative complexity and streamline licensing procedures for Idaho medical practitioners.

2024 H 490 requires applicants for various licenses in Idaho, including nursing, pharmacy, medicine, real estate, counseling, and driving instruction, be required to go through criminal background checks with fingerprinting, in order to enhance public safety when interacting with licensed professionals.

2024 SF 477 allows internationally-trained physicians to practice in Iowa under a provisional license if they meet requirements including examination, background check, residency and five years' practice abroad, and good standing with their home country medical board, in order to address physician shortages in the state. It also ensures minors' electronic health information will be made available to their parents.

2024 HB 2648 requires any proposed rule or regulation in Kansas that is expected to incur over $1 million in implementation and compliance costs in the first five years must be ratified by the legislature before it can go into effect, in order to increase oversight and reduce costs for Kansas taxpayers.

2024 HB 2353 extends the time for involuntary commitments in Kansas, creates safeguards regarding the need for a written statement from a qualified mental health professional for detention at state psychiatric hospitals, and prohibiting detention in jails or prisons, in order to both allow greater use of involuntary commitment for acute mental health issues while protecting the rights and wellbeing of those involuntarily committed.

Issues: Camping Bans; Homelessness; Mental Health Treatment; Public Safety; Sanctioned Camping Sites
Notes: 2024 HB 5 is a major overhaul of Kentucky's criminal statutes, and among many other provisions includes a ban on unsanctioned homeless camping, in order to reduce the dangers associated with homeless encampments, including drug use, violence, litter, and other nuisances.

2024 HB 566 removes unnecessary degree requirements from state jobs in Louisiana, in order to broaden the pool of eligible candidates to those without degrees but with relevant experience, allow more access to state employment, and allow open positions to be filled more efficiently.
2024 HB 904 requires public schools, colleges, and universities to report on their DEI programs, in order to increase transparency on potentially discriminatory DEI practices.

2024 HB 972 allows internationally-trained physicians to practice medicine in Louisiana as long as they are properly trained and in good standing in their home country, fluent in English, and have secured employment in a Louisiana hospital, in order to address physician shortages and make medical care more available in the state.
2024 HB 716 makes recognition of out-of-state occupational licenses easier for professionals moving into Louisiana, removing regulatory barriers and increasing the availability of services.
2024 SB 332 repeals the Louisiana Occupational Licensing Review Commission, which will reduce regulatory hurdles to innovation and small business in Louisiana.
2024 SB 60 makes recognition of out-of-state occupational licenses easier for professionals moving into Louisiana, removing regulatory barriers and increasing the availability of services.

2024 SB 231 expands the ability of Louisiana to use involuntary outpatient mental health treatment, with flexibility in treatment models and safeguards for the patients' rights, in order to make it easier to ensure mentally ill people receive the treatment they need.

2024 SB 894 includes regulatory sandbox provisions which allow Missouri businesses to test innovative products and services under a temporary waiver of certain state regulations, in order to foster innovation by providing a controlled environment for businesses to demonstrate new offerings without the immediate burden of full regulatory compliance.

2024 HB 33 includes, among many other budgetary provisions, a requirement that Ohio cease to require four-year degrees for hiring unless strictly necessary, with an eye to expanding employment opportunities to Ohioans with relevant experience but without degrees, and allowing open positions to be filled more efficiently.

2024 SB 1854 prohibits unauthorized camping in Oklahoma and allows law enforcement to issue a warning along with transportation to shelters or food pantries for first offenses. This will ensure that homeless people are off the streets and connected with the resources they need, which will help make Oklahoma communities cleaner and safer.

2024 HB 4159 allows out-of-state advanced practice nurses and physician assistants to provide telehealth and telemedicine services in South Carolina in order to alleviate physician shortages and make nursing care more accessible.

2024 SB 1881 updates the requirements for telemedicine, ensuring that Tennessee patients have access to the highest quality care and their personal data is protected when interacting in a telehealth environment.

2024 SB 2012 requires medical providers in Tennessee to prevent healthcare professionals and associated businesses from blocking information from patients, with exception for sensitive test results, in order to ensure patients are able to access their health records easily and electronically.

2024 HB 2900 requires Tennessee state and local government entities verify the citizenship or lawful residency status of any individual applying for public benefits, in order to verify that benefits are only going to the correct recipients, and allows for international physicians to more easily convert their provisional licenses into full licenses in order to increase availability of physicians in the state.

2024 SB 2689 creates a centralized system for case management, document management, electronic case filing, electronic payment methods, and data reporting for all state and local courts in Tennessee, in order to increase efficiency and decrease costs.

2024 SB 213 reforms Utah's criminal justice system and includes a provision whereby offenders can reduce their time on parole or probation by maintaining eligible employment, in order to ease the transition back into civilian life and reduce recidivism.

2024 HB 298 reorganizes Utah's Homeless Services Board and expands its responsibilities to include more data reporting and setting more ambitious goals to reduce homelessness, and requires Utah municipalities to enforce camping bans to receive state funds, in order to better address challenges associated with the homeless population.

2024 HB 213 includes several crime record privacy provisions, and includes regulatory sandbox provisions which allow Utah businesses to test innovative products and services under a temporary waiver of certain state regulations, in order to foster innovation by providing a controlled environment for businesses to demonstrate new offerings without the immediate burden of full regulatory compliance.

2024 SB 109 changes rules regarding probationers and parolees to more strongly punish violations, establishes a reentry program, and puts guardrails on when county jail officials can release individuals, in order to both properly punish crime and reduce recidivism.

2024 HB 995 allows foreign-trained physicians in Virginia to obtain a temporary license to practice if they trained at a WHO-recognized school and have practiced for at least five years, in order to increase the number of qualified doctors available to serve Virginia patients.

2024 AB 954 allows internationally trained physicians to practice in Wisconsin if they have an offer of full-time employment from a Wisconsin healthcare facility, in order to increase the number of qualified doctors available to serve Wisconsin patients.

2023 SB 1720, Arizona's general appropriations act, includes a homeless service grant pilot which would emphasize access to services, work opportunities, and transitional housing, in order to reduce homelessness and more productively offer services to move homeless individuals out of homelessness.
2023 HB 2055 allows those on probation in Arizona to earn a time credit for employment they maintain, in order to help ease reintegration of offenders into society and reduce recidivism.

2023 SB 1603 introduces new requirements for hospital price transparency in Arizona which require health care facilities to disclose cash prices for their most used treatments. This will allow patients to more easily shop for the lowest prices for their procedures and reduce the cost of care overall.

2023 CS/CS/SB 1310 allows Florida public-sector employers to remove degree requirements in favor of work experience or other qualification, in order to broaden the pool of eligible candidates to those without degrees but with relevant experience, allow more access to state employment, and allow open positions to be filled more efficiently.

2023 CS/CS/HB 931 requires Florida's college system to publish reports on intellectual freedom and viewport diversity in its institutions and bans political loyalty tests, in order to fight against DEI loyalty oaths and ensure true diversity of thought on Florida campuses.

2023 SB 3 requires Georgia state agencies to evaluate their job postings and find places where degree requirements can be exchanged for alternative qualifications, in order to broaden the pool of eligible candidates to those without degrees but with relevant experience, allow more access to state employment, and allow open positions to be filled more efficiently.

2023 SB 62 bans Georgia local governments from blocking the enforcement of camping bans, allows for diversion programs in lieu of arrest, and prohibits homeless people from being transported to other counties, in order to ensure that homeless people are off the streets and connected with the resources they need, which will help make Georgia's communities cleaner and safer.

2023 H 61 allows mental or behavioral health providers from other states to provide telehealth services in Idaho if in good standing in a jurisdiction with similar licensure requirements, in order to make mental health services more easily accessible for Idaho patients.

2023 S 1094 allows for temporary licenses for international doctors to practice medicine in Idaho if they have completed residency and at least three years of experience in their home country and agree to work for at least three years in a designated health shortage area, in order to address physician shortages and make healthcare more accessible to Idahoans.
2023 H 162 allows the establishment of a valid prescriber-patient relationship through telehealth in Idaho, in order to decrease cost and increase accessibility of medical care for Idaho patients.

2023 HB 417 removes postsecondary degree requirements for state jobs unless absolutely necessary, and offers tax credits for the hiring of interns and apprentices, in order to increase the viability of non-college educational paths, allow more access to state employment, and allow open positions to be filled more efficiently.

2023 HB 131 allows the Missouri government to pay its employees in biweekly installments, instead of semimonthly or monthly, along with accountability measures, in order to grant the government more flexibility in making its disbursements.
2023 SB 111 updates several provisions regarding state employees, including establishing regular reporting and uniform compensation, in order to increase efficiency in state spending in Missouri.

2023 H 87 allows North Carolina district attorneys to petition to modify probation terms in cases of either violation or good behavior, in order to ensure that those who are making progress can more easily return to society and that those likely to reoffend remain under supervision.

2023 SB 1451 allows international medical school graduates to receive a temporary license to practice in Tennessee, with possible transition to full licensure after two years in good standing, in order to alleviate physician shortages and increase access to care.

2023 SB 672 allows Tennessee advance practice nurses and physician assistants to make a preliminary determination of whether a person is suitable for emergency admission to treatment facilities for mental health issues, in order to share workload among qualified medical providers who are not doctors to allow doctors to focus their efforts where they are most needed, improving the efficiency and effectiveness of medical care for mental health patients.

2023 SB 817 prevents Tennessee from imposing divisive concepts such as systemic or inherent racism, different treatment based on race or sex, and categorical guilt of certain racial groups, in the form of loyalty oaths, discrimination in hiring or promotion, or mandatory training or indoctrination. This will ensure freedom of thought and freedom from institutional discrimination for students, faculty, and staff.

2023 HB 1213 allows Tennesseans to shop around for lower costs for treatment, and, if a covered person negotiates a lower cost for service than what their insurance would pay, that savings would be credited toward the patient's deductible, in order to incentivize patients and providers alike to reduce healthcare costs.

2023 SB 1437 removes the distance from home restrictions on Tennessee minors' motorcycle learner's permits if the minor is supervised by a parent or legal guardian also operating a motorcycle, reducing unnecessary regulatory burden while ensuring young riders are adequately supervised.

2023 SB 17 restricts DEI offices in Texas universities and prevents compelled DEI statements, trainings, or discrimination based on race, sex, color, ethnicity, or national origin, in order to ensure freedom of thought and freedom from institutional discrimination for students, faculty, and staff.

2023 HB 8 requires Texas higher education institutions to share detailed information on costs and job prospects of their programs, in order to ensure prospective students are armed with sufficient information to choose the program that will be best for their career aspirations.
2023 HB 1038 introduces reporting requirements for state lending and credit support programs in Texas, in order to ensure transparency and accountability in those programs.

2023 HB 159 allows for healthcare providers in other states to provide telemedicine services in Utah under a temporary license, in order to alleviate physician shortages and make health care more accessible to Utah patients.

2023 HB 499 overhauls Utah's homeless services strategy by requiring municipalities to enforce camping bans to receive funds, creates a winter response task force, and allocates funding to municipalities based on available shelter beds, in order to improve the quality and effectiveness of Utah's services for the homeless.
2023 SB 70 is the Wisconsin state budget - our interest UNCLEAR.

2022 SB 1262 requires reporting on all bond issues and securities longer than a year, as well as on lending and credit support programs, in order to allow Arizona investors greater transparency on their investment options.

2022 HB 2731 expands the regulatory sandbox program, which allows Arizona businesses to test innovative products and services without the normal licensing requirements with limited market access, by allowing a broader range of products to be included in the program. It does this in order to foster innovation by providing a controlled environment for businesses to demonstrate new offerings without the immediate burden of full regulatory compliance.

2022 HB 2612 reforms Arizona's occupational licensing laws, making it easier to transfer licenses without fees in industries like real estate, healthcare, liquor, and lottery sales, in order to reduce regulations and allow for more innovation with less red tape.

2022 CS/CS/SB 752 includes several reforms to probation in Florida, including allowing probationers to report in remotely and incentives for educational advancement, in order to ease the return of those on probation back into society and to reduce recidivism.

2022 SB 7044 allows Florida to perform post-tenure reviews of state university faculty, mandates transparency in tuition and fees, requires detailed syllabi and course lists to be published, and allows flexibility in choosing an accreditation agency, in order to increase transparency and reduce costs for Florida students.

2022 HB 978 bans camping on public property around highways in Tennessee, in order to reduce the dangers associated with homeless encampments, including drug use, violence, litter, and other nuisances.

2022 SB 43 eases occupational licensing requirements on several fields in Utah, including speech-language pathology, environmental health science, and cosmetology, in order to reduce regulatory burdens and encourage innovation and competition in licensed fields.

2022 HB 363 extends civil commitment powers in Utah, including extending the maximum period for temporary civil commitment, allows mental health evaluations via telehealth, and gives courts flexibility for ordering commitment, outpatient treatment, or dismissal, in order to ensure cases of acute mental health crisis are given appropriate treatment.
2022 HB 412 creates a probation and parole employment incentive program in Utah, in order to enhance employment outcomes for individuals on parole and felony probation, thereby reducing recidivism.

2022 HB 440 creates a new homeless network steering committee in Utah and changes the funding formula to direct funding to support homeless services in a more cost-effective manner. It also restricts funding for municipalities that do not enforce camping bans to ensure accountability.

2022 SB 606 introduces new publishing and reporting requirements for the state's transportation infrastructure loan program, in order to increase transparency and ensure funds are being spent appropriately.
2021 HB 2168 requires law enforcement agencies to collect and report data on use-of-force incidents involving their officers, in order to increase transparency and public oversight of police actions.

2021 HB 2787 redefines "moral turpitude" in Arizona law in a way to allow some individuals with criminal records to still be able to obtain occupational licenses, in order to increase opportunities for reformed former criminals, to reduce regulation, and to further competition and innovation.

2021 HB 7051 reforms law enforcement hiring practices in Florida to require disclosure of any past resignations, detailed reasons for separations from previous employment, and new training in use of proportional force and deescalation techniques, in order to reduce unnecessary use of force by law enforcement and ensure citizens are properly protected.

2021 CS/CS/CS/HB 1507 creates an Office of Reimagining Education and Career Help in the office of the Florida governor and creates several other programs including tuition assistance for workforce training and tuition reimbursement if a student fails to find a job in his/her trained field, in order to more directly align education with positive career outcomes.

2021 HB 591 expands the scope of professionals who can conduct emergency mental illness or substance abuse evaluations in Georgia to include marriage and family therapists, psychologists, clinical social workers, licensed professional counselors, and clinical nurse specialists can perform these tasks in lieu of physicians, freeing up some demands on physicians' time and ensuring that patients in need can be seen as quickly as possible.

2021 SB 53 is a major reform of Missouri criminal law practices, which among other provisions includes requirements for use of force training, enhanced background checks, prohibitions on chokeholds, and providing stress management programs for law enforcement. It also creates a database of police use of force incidents, all in order to provide transparency and accountability for law enforcement and to ensure citizens are receiving proper protection.

2021 S300 is a major reform of North Carolina criminal law practices, which among other provisions includes increases in protections, training, and oversight for law enforcement, focused on reducing excessive use of force and using body cameras, in order to provide transparency and accountability for law enforcement and to ensure citizens are receiving proper protection.

2021 SB 1380 prohibits the use of choke holds by Tennessee law enforcement and requires training in deescalation, in order to increase accountability for law enforcement and ensure citizens' rights are protected.

2021 HB 1925 bans public camping in Texas. This will ensure that homeless people are off the streets and connected with the resources they need, which will help make Texas communities cleaner and safer.

2021 SB 123 requires collection of data on use-of-force incidents by Wisconsin law enforcement, in order to increase transparency and accountability for law enforcement to ensure citizens are receiving proper protection.
